ygData.subject: Re: Characters in EQ
ygData.msgSnippet: The sex of the art director means nothing.  As a female who has worked in three highly technical and previously all-male (as well as still 95% male) fields.  I
ygData.messageBody:
The sex of the art director means nothing. As a female who has worked in
three highly technical and previously all-male (as well as still 95% male)
fields. I will say that some of the most discrimanatory and backwards (as to
sexism) statements and decisions have been made by females. Who either:
- honestly believe they are inferior
- fear challenging a male as a "lone" female may cost them thier job at the
extreme, or some peer respect at a minimum (often it does)
- are trying to prove they can be "one of the boys" and understand the
male world (not always bad - but means you'll see females making oddly
male choices).

One example.
I was once called on the carpet and emphatically told to "never, ever again
ask a question of a male in a meeting when the question *may* lead him to
discover that something could have been done better (and thus insult him)"
in the late 80's BY A FEMALE. Of course, the muckety-muck male, who's
response
to my technical question was "I'll look into that", was incredibly pleased
I'd given him a good question to ask his techies and thrilled when they fixed
the problem and made him LOOK GOOD! The techies in question were my office
mates and had been dying for resources or an excuse to fix that problem, and
thanked me for creating the opportunity to get it "air time" at the
muckety-muck
level so they could fix it. The male was ever after appreciative of my
technical
problem solving to the point of wanting me to transfer to his group, and the
female became a deadly political enemy. We were the only two females in
the area.
The company was no backwoods small shop, but the state headquarters for one
of the
top 3 phone/internet providers in the country.

Sure, EQ graphics are very sexist. I'm a female, and knowing what I know
about internet and RPG likely customers, I very well might have decided that
the current graphics were the right job decision. Yep, as a female. Its
still sexist, and I still hate the lack of graphics which would appeal to
female player.

>> Women, they look much more like Rangers than their female counterparts.
>> It seems quite obvious the Dev Team is an all male affair.
>>
>
>Heh. So many people say this but in fact the art director was a woman.
